item.description:
By: John Shepler The concept of “Bring Your Own Device” (BYOD) can be a real headache for IT managers. While employees may enjoy the convenience, it poses a significant risk to a company’s sensitive data. When personal devices connect to the company network, carefully constructed security protocols are often bypassed. So, what can be done? Many companies address this issue by drawing a hard line. Recognizing the challenges of managing diverse personal devices, they prohibit their use for business purposes altogether...

item.title: Is Managed WiFi Right for You?
item.description:
By: John Shepler Broadband internet access is widely available and has become a standard expectation. Consumers rely on it to stay connected while on the move, and businesses use it to provide connectivity to customers and allow employees to work flexibly. Considering 3G and 4G cellular? Cellular broadband on smartphones is excellent for wide area coverage, but it has limitations. Data usage limits can lead to unexpectedly high costs. Additionally, many computers, tablets, and other devices lack built-in cellular connectivity, even if users are willing to pay extra for it...

item.title: Sophos has simplified the process of securing corporate information on mobile devices
item.description:
Source: Sophos website. Sophos recently launched Sophos Mobile Control 5 (SMC 5), a software solution designed to differentiate personal and company data on devices to enhance corporate data security. Managing devices like laptops, tablets, and smartphones often involves individual configuration, updates, and management. SMC 5 simplifies this process for IT administrators by allowing them to establish user-specific rules once to protect company data stored on the device or in personal cloud storage...
